title-group.article-title: ATP-Induced Currents Carried Through P2X7 Receptor in Rat Myometrial Cells

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Higashihiroshima Medical Center, Higashihiroshima, Japan
2Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Graduate School of Biomedical Sciences, Hiroshima University, Hiroshima, Japan
3Department of Physical Therapy, Faculty of Health Sciences, Hiroshima International University, Higashi-Hiroshima, Japan
4Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Hiroshima Prefectural Hospital, Hiroshima, Japan

author-notes.corresp: Hiroshi Miyoshi, Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Higashihiroshima Medical Center, 513 Saijyou-cho Jike, Higashihiroshima, Hiroshima 739-0041, Japan Email: miyoshi_hiroshi@hiro-hosp.jp

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: The functional significance of purinergic P2 receptors in the myometrium is unclear. We previously reported the ATP-induced ionic currents in rat myometrial cells, causing uterine contractility. The aim of this study is to determine the main P2X receptors that carry the adenosine triphosphate (ATP)-induced currents.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: We cloned predominantly expressed P2X7 receptors from rat myometrium and transfected into cultured COS-7 cells. Reconstructed P2X7 receptor currents were characterized using the whole-cell patch clamp method.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Extracellular ATP induced currents through P2X7 receptors with effective concentration (EC50) of 155 μmol/L, without desensitization. The myometrial P2X7 receptor was permeable to multiple monovalent cations with conductances ranked as K+>Cs+>Li+>Na+. It was activated by P2X receptor agonists, with effectiveness ranked as 2′,3′-O-(4-benzoylbenzoyl)-ATP (Bz-ATP)>>ATP>αβ-methylene ATP (αβ-MeATP)>2-methylthio ATP (2-MeSATP)>uridine triphosphate (UTP)>guanosine triphosphate (GTP)>adenosine diphosphate (ADP). These currents were blocked by selective P2X7 receptor antagonists and extracellular Mg2+.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: P2X7 receptors carry ATP-induced currents in rat myometrial cells.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Prevention of preterm birth, in order to improve perinatal morbidity and mortality, is one of the most important aims of perinatal medical care. Preterm birth is often caused by maternal infection or enhancement of uterine contractility, the control of which is essential to avoid preterm delivery. 1 However, the mechanisms underlying enhanced uterine contractions and their inhibition by tocolytic agents are poorly understood.

Contractions of uterine smooth muscle cells are regulated by Ca2+ influx through nonselective cation channels (NSCCs) as well as L-type Ca2+ channels. Receptor-operated NSCCs have been identified in a variety of smooth muscles, including noradrenaline- or calcium-activated NSCCs in portal vein smooth muscle cells, 2,3 whereas acetylcholine (Ach)-activated NSCCs were reported to induce depolarization that led to the contraction of iliac, gastric, and tracheal smooth muscles. 4–7 In our previous reports, the NSCC current and adenosine triphosphate (ATP)-induced currents were identified in rat myometrial smooth muscle cells and have shown to play a role in the regulation of uterine contractions. 8
,9 Adenosine triphosphate–enhanced ion conductance in the myometrium has been documented in cultured uterine smooth muscle cells from pregnant rats to regulate myometrial cell contractions. 10 Adenosine triphosphate was found to induce depolarization following initial hyperpolarization. 11

More recently, some purinergic P2 receptor agonists of the myometrium were reported to mediate uterine contractions. 12 P2 receptors are subclassified as ionotropic P2X and metabotropic P2Y receptors; 7 subtypes of P2X receptors and 8 subtypes of P2Y receptors have been cloned. 13
,14 P2X receptors are present in most organs and are involved in a wide range of physiological processes including regulation of smooth muscle contractions. 15 For example, the expression profile of 7 P2X receptors has been determined in the human bladder. 16 P2X7 receptors have been identified in human smooth muscle of saphenous vein and their activation have been shown to induce muscle contractions. 17

We previously investigated the expression profiles of P2X receptors in the rat myometrium, where we found P2X4 and P2X7 receptors to predominate. 18 The expression levels of these P2X receptors were dramatically increased under conditions that mimicked preterm delivery, produced by the administration of the antiprogesterone agent mifepristone or by lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-induced uterine inflammation, suggesting that the enhancement of P2X receptors is related to preterm delivery in this rat model. We also concluded that ATP-induced currents in pregnant rat myometrial cells are carried by P2X7 receptors. 9

The present study clarified the P2X receptor subtypes that generate ATP-induced conductance in rat myometrial cells. Myometrial P2X4 and P2X7 receptor genes were transfected into cultured cells, and the reconstructed ATP-induced currents were characterized through these P2X receptors.

sec.title: Animal Care
sec.p: All procedures involving animal handling and experimental protocols complied with the Guidelines for the Committee of Research Facilities for Laboratory Animal Science from Hiroshima University (Hiroshima, Japan), and the guidelines were issued by the US National Institutes of Health.

sec.title: Isolation of P2X Messenger RNAs
sec.p: Total cellular RNA was isolated from all layer of myometrial tissue dissected from pregnant Sprague-Dawley rats at day 19 using the TRIzol protocol (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, California). Messenger RNA (mRNA) was purified by a FirstTrack mRNA purification kit (Invitrogen), and first- and second-strand complementary DNA (cDNA) were synthesized with a Marathon cDNA kit using poly(dT) primer (BD Biosciences, Franklin Lakes, New Jersey). Myometrial P2X4 and P2X7 cDNAs were cloned into pcDNA3.1(–) mammalian expression vectors (Invitrogen). All resulting constructs were confirmed by restriction mapping and sequencing using an ABI PRISM 310 Genetic Analyzer (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, California). P2X4 and P2X7 receptor sequences are deposited with the DNA Data Bank of Japan (DDBJ) data libraries under accession numbers X87763 and NM019256, respectively.

sec.title: Transient Transfection and Cell Culture
sec.p: Cloned P2X4 and P2X7 cDNAs were transiently transfected into the COS-7 cell line within the vector pCA-GFP, containing the S65A bright green fluorescent protein mutant to detect transfected cells. Transfection was performed with Effectine reagent (Qiagen K. K., Tokyo, Japan), and the cells were grown to 50% confluency in Dulbecco modified Eagle’s medium (Invitrogen), containing 10% fetal bovine serum (BioWhittaker, Walkersville, Maryland), 30 U/mL penicillin G (Invitrogen), and 30 μg/mL streptomycin (Invitrogen), in a humidified atmosphere of 5% CO2 and 95% air at 37°C. Transfected cells were used for electrophysiological experiments through posttransfection day 3. Transfection-positive cells were identified by epifluorescence microscopy performed using a 100-watt mercury lamp and a standard fluorescein isothiocyanate filter set (TM2000; Nikon, Tokyo, Japan). Single isolated green fluorescent cells were used for patch-clamp studies.

sec.title: Patch-Clamp Experiments
sec.p: The cultured cells were resuspended from the culture dish by treatment with trypsin-EDTA solution (Sigma Chemicals, St Louis, Missouri) for 30 seconds. The suspended COS-7 cells were placed into 0.5-mL recording chambers mounted on an inverted microscope (TM2000; Nikon). The cells were used for the patch-clamp study after one hour of re-suspension and used up within 8 hours. The conventional whole-cell patch-clamp method 19 was applied. The patch pipette was connected to a voltage clamp amplifier (Axopatch 200B; Axon Instruments, Burlingame, California), and test pulses were generated and the current recorded using a computer connected to a direct memory access (DMA) interface (DigiData 1200; Axon) using pCLAMP software (Axon). The recording chamber contained an Ag-AgCl2 pellet as the ground electrode. All experiments were carried out at room temperature.

A step pulse or ramp pulse protocol was used for recording ion currents. The holding potential was set at −40 mV in all experiments. The ramp pulse protocol used a constant preconditioning pulse of +40 mV for 100 milliseconds and successive ramp pulses from +40 to −100 mV for 350 milliseconds. Data were plotted as the current generated in response to the ramp pulse against the membrane potential from −100 to +40 mV, without subtracting the leak current.

sec.title: Solutions for Patch-Clamp Experiments
sec.p: The compositions of the solution for patch-clamp experiments were as reported previously. 9 The standard external solution contained 125.4 mmol/L NaCl, 20 mmol/L tetraethylammonium chloride (TEA-Cl), 0.1 mmol/L MgCl2, 11 mmol/L glucose, and 5 mmol/L 4-(2-hydroxyethyl)-1-piperazineethanesulfonic acid (HEPES; pH 7.4), with 5 μmol/L nifedipine (Sigma), 30 μmol/L LaCl3, and 1 μmol/L CaCl2. When measuring reversal potentials to determine the ion selectivity of the P2X channels, KCl, CsCl, and LiCl in external solutions were replaced with equimolar NaCl in the standard external solution. The internal solution within the pipette contained 125 mmol/L Cs-aspartate, 20 mmol/L TEA-Cl, 5 mmol/L MgATP, 1.2 mmol/L CaCl2, 5 mmol/L ethylene glycol tetraacetic acid (EGTA), and 10 mmol/L HEPES (pH 7.2).

sec.title: Drugs, Cells, and Data Analysis
sec.p: All nucleotides, ATP, adenosine diphosphate (ADP), guanosine triphosphate (GTP), and uridine triphosphate (UTP), were purchased from Sigma. The ATP analogs, 2-methylthio ATP (2-MeSATP), αβ-methylene ATP (αβ-MeATP), and 2′,3′-O-(4-benzoylbenzoyl)-ATP (Bz-ATP), as well as the P2X receptor antagonists, suramin and pyridoxal-phosphate-6-azophenyl-2′,4′-disulphonic acid (PPADS), were purchased from Sigma. The selective P2X7 receptor antagonist 3-(5-(2,3-dichlorophenyl)-1 H-tetrazol-1-yl) methyl pyridine (A438079) was purchased from Tocris (Bristol, UK). The cultured COS-7 cell line was purchased from Riken (Tsukuba, Japan). Dose–response curve fitting was carried out using Origin 8.0 software (Origin Lab, Northampton, Massachusetts). Results were expressed as means ± standard deviation (SD), otherwise stated.

sec.title: Desensitization of P2X4 and P2X7 Channel Currents
sec.p: Ionic currents in P2X4- or P2X7-transfected COS-7 cells were induced by the external application of 0.1 mmol/L ATP. Currents through the P2X4 receptor were induced and decayed gradually to less than 10% of the maximum amplitude within 1 minute, as shown in Figure 1a. P2X7 receptor currents were not reduced (Figure 1b). Heterologously expressed P2X7 channels were found to be resistant to desensitization.

caption.p: Desensitization to ATP. Time courses of current amplitudes in the presence of 0.1 mmol/L ATP are shown in (a) P2X4-expressed COS-7 cells and (b) P2X7-expressed COS-7 cells. ATP application at a constant voltage of −40 mV induced an inward current, showing no desensitization (b). P2X4 currents in (a) were suppressed to less than 10% of the initial amplitude in 1 minute. Washout of ATP immediately abolished the current. ATP indicates adenosine triphosphate.

sec.p: To confirm that ATP-induced currents in rat myometrial cells are carried by P2X7 channels, we carried out further analysis of their properties in COS-7 cells.

sec.title: ATP-induced P2X7 Receptor Currents in COS-7 Cells
sec.p: Ionic conductance was induced by external ATP in P2X7-expressing COS-7 cells at concentrations more than 10 μmol/L. The currents showed no time-dependent changes, and conductance was shown to have a linear relationship with membrane voltage (Figure 2a). The activation of these currents was dependent on external ATP concentration, in the range of 10 μmol/L to 1 mmol/L. The ATP median effective concentration (EC50) was estimated to be 152 ± 12 μmol/L (n = 8, mean ± standard error of the mean [SEM]), as shown in Figure 2b.

caption.p: Dose–response curve of P2X7 receptor for ATP. (a) Currents recorded at ATP concentrations between 10 μmol/L and 500 μmol/L using ramp pulse protocol from −100 to +40 mV. “cont” curve shows recording in the absence of ATP. Current activation was detected at ATP concentrations as low as 10 μmol/L. (b) Mean current amplitudes at −40 mV relative to those measured in the presence of 1 mmol/L ATP; bars show SDs. EC50 for ATP was estimated to be 152 ± 12 μmol/L (n = 8, mean ± SEM) from the fitted curve to the Boltzmann equation. ATP indicates adenosine triphosphate; SD, standard deviation; EC50, effective concentration; SEM standard error of the mean.

sec.title: Selectivity for Monovalent Cations of P2X7 Receptor
sec.p: P2X receptors are classified as NSCCs and are permeable to several monovalent cations. We examined the selectivity of the P2X7 receptor for monovalent cations by measuring reversal potentials for each cation under different ionic conditions, using Li+, Cs+, or K+ as main cations in the external solution. The reversal potentials were determined as the intersection of the current–voltage curves in the presence or absence of ATP. The reversal potentials for 125.4 mmol/L K+, Cs+, Li+, and the standard (Na+) external solution were 10.5 ± 1.7 mV (n = 19), 8.0 ± 2.7 mV (n = 13), 6.7 ± 2.7 mV (n = 12), and 1.2 ± 1.8 mV (n = 22), respectively. Thus, the permeability of the channels for each monovalent cation could be ranked as K+>Cs+>Li+>Na+.

sec.title: Effects of Agonists on P2X7 Receptor Currents
sec.p: P2X receptors are also known to be sensitive to nucleotide compounds other than ATP, including ADP, GTP, and UTP, and to ATP analogs such as 2-MeSATP, αβ-MeATP, and Bz-ATP. We investigated the effects of various agonists on P2X7 receptor currents in COS-7 cells (Figure 3). Current amplitudes activated by 0.1 mmol/L ADP, GTP, and UTP were 10% ± 7% (n = 6), 29% ± 13% (n = 7), and 39% ± 18% (n = 12) of the control induced by 0.1 mmol/L ATP, respectively. The ATP analogs 2-MeSATP, αβ-MeATP, and Bz-ATP induced currents with amplitudes that were 55% ± 17% (n = 10), 85% ± 25% (n = 10), and 437% ± 185% (n = 17) of those induced by ATP, respectively. The most potent agonist for the P2X7 receptor in COS-7 cells was Bz-ATP.

caption.p: Effects of ATP analogs and nucleotides. Amplitudes of induced currents in response to each agonist at 0.1 mmol/L compared with those induced subsequently by 0.1 mmol/L ATP in the same cell. Results are shown as means ± SDs, with the value for ATP taken as unity. ATP indicates adenosine triphosphate; SD, standard deviation.

sec.title: Effects of Antagonists on P2X7 Receptor Currents
sec.p: We examined the effects of P2X receptor antagonists on P2X7 receptor currents in COS-7 cells. At a concentration of 0.1 mmol/L, suramin blocked the currents by 42% ± 12% (n = 9) and PPADS blocked the currents by 56% ± 9% (n = 10) as shown in Figure 4. In addition, these currents were sensitive to the selective P2X7 receptor antagonist A438079 and were reversibly blocked by 49% ± 7%, 83% ± 17%, and 90% ± 8% at concentrations of 0.01, 0.1, and 1 mmol/L (n = 8), respectively.

caption.p: Effect of P2X antagonists, suramin, PPADS, and A438079. Partial inhibition by suramin (A) and PPADS (B). Approximately 60% inhibition by suramin at highest concentration of 300 µmol/L, and 60% inhibition by PPADS at 100 µmol/L. A438079 blocked these currents by about 50% at 1 µmol/L and 90% at 100 µmol/L. (C) Amplitudes of currents measured at −40 mV at each concentration of suramin, PPADS, and A438079 shown relative to those in the absence of antagonists. PPADS indicates pyridoxal-phosphate-6-azophenyl-2′,4′-disulphonic acid.

sec.p: P2X7 receptor currents in COS-7 cells were also inhibited in a concentration-dependent manner by Mg2+ (Figure 5). The IC50 was calculated as 0.12 mmol/L (n = 7), based on the data pooled from 8 cells.

caption.p: Effect of extracellular Mg2+ on ATP-induced currents in P2X7-expressed COS-7 cells; dose-dependent inhibition by Mg2+. Amplitudes of currents measured at −40mV shown in relation to that in the presence of 0.01 mmol/L Mg2+. Mean amplitudes plotted as a function of Mg2+ concentration (n = 7; error bars represent SDs). IC50 calculated as 0.12 mmol/L from the curve shown, which was obtained by fitting the data to the Boltzmann equation.

sec.title: Comment
sec.p: This study cloned P2X4 and P2X7 receptor cDNAs and transfected them into the cultured COS-7 cell line. The whole-cell patch-clamp method was applied to transfected COS-7 cells to characterize reconstructed myometrial P2X4 or P2X7 receptors, allowing us to compare reconstructed P2X currents with ATP-induced currents in myometrial cells. P2X7 receptors are NSCCs that are permeable to various monovalent ions. The permeability order of myometrial P2X7 receptors for monovalent cations in this study was K+>Cs+>Li+>Na+, which was similar to ATP-induced currents in rat myometrial cells. 9

P2X7 receptors expressed in COS-7 cells showed no desensitization for at least 5 minutes, as observed for the ATP-induced currents of rat myometrial cells, 9 whereas P2X4 receptor currents declined to less than 10% within 1 minute. These findings show that the ATP-induced currents in myometrial cells are mainly carried by P2X7 receptors. Desensitization to agonists is a common characteristic of P2X receptors, and its time course can be used for subclassification purposes. P2X1 and P2X3 have thus been shown to desensitize rapidly, while P2X2, P2X4, and P2X5 gradually desensitize over 30 to 60 seconds. However, the P2X7 receptor was previously shown to have no desensitization, 20
,21 which is in agreement with our results.

P2X7 receptors expressed in COS-7 cells were dose-dependently activated by ATP at concentrations higher than 10 μmol/L; the mean EC50 of ATP was calculated to be 152 μmol/L. This value is comparable to that of the ATP-induced currents in myometrial cells (74 μmol/L). P2Z-like receptors in toad gastric smooth muscles 22 required 150 μmol/L ATP to induce the current and recorded an EC50 of 700 μmol/L. An EC50 of 780 μmol/L has been measured for the human recombinant P2X7 receptor, 23 while a 10-fold smaller EC50 value was reported for the rat recombinant P2X7 receptor. 24 The relatively low EC50 for ATP in the present study indicates that the P2X7 receptors in rat myometrial cells belong to a group with high sensitivity to ATP.

P2X7 receptors expressed in COS-7 cells were activated by various nucleotides and ATP analogs, especially Bz-ATP. This is widely recognized as a strong P2X7-selective receptor agonist 25 with a potency 4.8-fold higher than that of ATP in rat microglia, 26 and 5-fold higher than ATP in a neuroblastoma cell line. 27 In this study, Bz-ATP enhanced current 4.3-fold compared with ATP, and the potency was higher than the response of ATP-induced current in rat myometrial cells. The application of αβ-MeATP and 2MeATP also induced P2X7 receptor current, but these were smaller than those with ATP. Our results ranked the effectiveness of ATP analogs in the order Bz-ATP >>ATP>αβ-MeATP>2MeATP, which is in good agreement with the reports for other P2X7 receptors 27
,28 and is similar to that of ATP-induced currents in rat myometrial cells. 9 These findings support the idea that the P2X7 receptor is the main charge carrier for ATP-induced currents in rat myometrial cells.

P2X7 receptor currents were sensitive to some antagonists such as suramin and PPADS, but the blockade was partial and reversible even at saturated doses. Using the more specific P2X7 receptor inhibitor A438079, receptor currents were reversibly blocked by about 50% with 1 µmol/L, 83% with 10 µmol/L, and 90% with 100 µmol/L. This sensitivity was comparable to a previous report in which Bz-ATP-evoked currents were inhibited by 0.3 to 3 µmol/L A438079 in nonneuronal cells of dorsal root ganglia. 29 A438079 had a more potent effect on expressed P2X7 receptor current in the present study than on ATP-induced currents in myometrial cells, suggesting that the latter has additional unknown contributors. These pharmacological findings also support the notion that ATP-induced currents in myometrial cells are carried by P2X7 receptors.

In this study, the P2X7 receptor was blocked by Mg2+, as previously observed in rat myometrial cells. 9 The IC50 of 0.12 mmol/L was, however, smaller than that of ATP-induced currents in myometrial cells. This blockade is a mechanism to inhibit uterine contractions by suppressing the depolarization of cell membranes in rat myometrial cells. As the physiological concentration of extracellular Mg2+ is approximately 0.45 mmol/L in rat serum, 30 over 75% of a cell’s capacity to conduct ionic currents should be blocked at the baseline Mg2+ concentration used. However, blockage could be carried out at concentrations of Mg2+ higher than 0.45 mmol/L. Thus, therapeutic administration of Mg2+ to inhibit uterine contractility in preterm delivery could be explained through the suppressive effect of Mg2+ on P2X7 currents.

Maternal inflammation, such as chorioamnionitis, has been reported to be related to preterm delivery. 31 –33 Previously, we showed that the expression levels of P2X4 and P2X7 receptors were dramatically enhanced in inflammatory and hormonally induced preterm labor model rats by the application of LPS and the antiprogesterone mifepristone. 18 The increase in P2X7 expression in response to inflammation should enhance uterine contractility and the influx of calcium ions to activate inflammatory cascades. The P2X7 receptor might therefore be a mechanism of preterm labor.

In conclusion, all the observed properties of cloned P2X7 receptors from the pregnant rat myometrium in the present study were in good agreement with those of ATP-induced currents in freshly isolated myometrial cells. Therefore, we conclude that ATP-induced currents in rat myometrial cells are mainly carried by P2X7 receptors. Further studies on human P2X receptors might lead to the elucidation of the mechanisms underlying preterm labor and the development of new treatments.
